Title.evidence: This was an open-label, randomized clinical trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This was an open-label, randomized clinical trial conducted at 14 German hospitals.

Participants.evidence: All patients with third- or fourth-degree haemorrhoids undergoing haemorrhoidectomy were considered eligible for selection in the intervention (no dressing) or control group (tamponade applied).

Intervention.evidence: intervention (no dressing) or control group (tamponade applied)

Objective.evidence: The aim of the study was to investigate whether the omission of tamponade dressings after haemorrhoidectomy reduces postoperative pain without increasing the risk of severe bleeding.

Method_Outcome.evidence: maximum pain intensity within 48 h after surgery was compared between the groups

Blinding.evidence: This was an open-label, randomized clinical trial

Number_Randomised.evidence: 754 were randomized and 725 received intervention (366 patients in the intervention and 359 patients in the control group)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The absolute difference for the severe bleeding rate was −0.03 per cent with the 90 per cent confidence interval ranging from −1.47 per cent to +1.41 per cent

Harms.evidence: In each group, five patients (1.4 per cent) experienced severe bleeding.
